channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Catalysis of an S<sub>N</sub>2 pathway by geometric preorganization
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07811-4

Catalysis of an SN2 pathway by geometric preorganization
item.dc:title: Catalysis of an S<sub>N</sub>2 pathway by geometric preorganization
item.dc:creator: Gabriel J. Lovinger
Marcus H. Sak
Eric N. Jacobsen

item.title: Long COVID lung damage linked to immune system response
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02352-2

Inhibiting a protein associated with chronic inflammation improves lung health in mice with COVID-19.
item.dc:title: Long COVID lung damage linked to immune system response
item.dc:creator: Helena Kudiabor

item.title: Three-year delay for Indian census frustrates researchers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02321-9

Without up-to-date data on the population, scientists say studies on fertility, migration and health outcomes have become unreliable.
item.dc:title: Three-year delay for Indian census frustrates researchers
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: What is it like to attend a predatory conference?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02358-w

Nature sent a reporter to find out as part of an investigation into dud events.
item.dc:title: What is it like to attend a predatory conference?
item.dc:creator: Christine Ro

item.title: A roadmap for affordable genetic medicines
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07800-7

A roadmap for affordable genetic medicines
item.dc:title: A roadmap for affordable genetic medicines
item.dc:creator: Melinda Kliegman
Manar Zaghlula
Susan Abrahamson
Jonathan H. Esensten
Ross Wilson
Fyodor D. Urnov
Jennifer A. Doudna

item.title: The plastic that biodegrades in your home compost
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02356-y

Enzymes embedded directly into the material allows PLA plastic to completely break down — plus a gel that can safely store proteins for shipping.
item.dc:title: The plastic that biodegrades in your home compost
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Emily Bates

item.title: This tiny solar-powered flyer weighs less than a paper plane
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02316-6

The 4.21g rotorcraft — dubbed CoulombFly — could forge a path to new kinds of tiny aerial vehicles.
item.dc:title: This tiny solar-powered flyer weighs less than a paper plane
item.dc:creator: Dan Fox

item.title: The enduring world forest carbon sink
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07602-x

Data from boreal, temperate and tropical forests over the past three decades reveal that the global forest carbon sink has remained steady during that time, despite considerable regional variation.
item.dc:title: The enduring world forest carbon sink
item.dc:creator: Yude Pan
Richard A. Birdsey
Oliver L. Phillips

item.title: Symbolic recording of signalling and cis-regulatory element activity to DNA
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07706-4

Enhancer-driven genomic recording of transcriptional activity in multiplex (ENGRAM) is used for multiplex recording of the cell-type-specific activities of dozens to hundreds of cis-regulatory elements with high fidelity, sensitivity and reproducibility.
item.dc:title: Symbolic recording of signalling and cis-regulatory element activity to DNA
item.dc:creator: Wei Chen

item.title: Giant chiral magnetoelectric oscillations in a van der Waals multiferroic
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07678-5

Precision measurement of the dynamical magnetoelectric coupling in an exfoliated van der Waals multiferroic shows a giant natural optical activity at terahertz frequencies.
item.dc:title: Giant chiral magnetoelectric oscillations in a van der Waals multiferroic
item.dc:creator: Frank Y. Gao

item.title: Superconductivity in pressurized trilayer La4Ni3O10−δ single crystals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07553-3

The application of pressure effectively suppresses the spin–charge order in trilayer nickelate La4Ni3O10−δ single crystals, leading to the emergence of superconductivity.
item.dc:title: Superconductivity in pressurized trilayer La4Ni3O10−δ single crystals

item.title: Inhibition of IL-11 signalling extends mammalian healthspan and lifespan
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07701-9

IL-11 is identified as a key regulator of ERK–AMPK–mTORC1 signalling, metabolism, inflammation and age-related disease and lifespan in mouse and human.
item.dc:title: Inhibition of IL-11 signalling extends mammalian healthspan and lifespan

item.title: An engineered enzyme embedded into PLA to make self-biodegradable plastic
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07709-1

Embedding of a new engineered thermostable hydrolase into polymer materials enables the production of biodegradable and home-compostable plastics suitable for industrial packaging applications.
item.dc:title: An engineered enzyme embedded into PLA to make self-biodegradable plastic

item.title: Thresholds for adding degraded tropical forest to the conservation estate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07657-w

An analysis of the impact of logging intensity on biodiversity in tropical forests in Sabah, Malaysia, identifies a threshold of tree biomass removal below which logged forests still have conservation value.
item.dc:title: Thresholds for adding degraded tropical forest to the conservation estate

item.title: Adaptation to photoperiod via dynamic neurotransmitter segregation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07692-7

Changes in day length, conveyed by the preoptic area, drive axonal neurotransmitter reorganization in median raphe dual serotonin–glutamate neurons to regulate behaviour and sleep timing, highlighting a photoperiod-sensitive brain circuit.
item.dc:title: Adaptation to photoperiod via dynamic neurotransmitter segregation
item.dc:creator: G. Maddaloni
Y. J. Chang
R. A. Senft
S. M. Dymecki

item.title: A hot-Jupiter progenitor on a super-eccentric retrograde orbit
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07688-3

The spectroscopic and photometric observations of a high-mass, transiting warm Jupiter, TIC 241249530 b, with an orbital eccentricity of 0.94, provide evidence that hot Jupiters may have formed by means of a high-eccentricity tidal-migration pathway.
item.dc:title: A hot-Jupiter progenitor on a super-eccentric retrograde orbit
item.dc:creator: Arvind F. Gupta

item.title: Psilocybin desynchronizes the human brain
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07624-5

Healthy adults were tracked before, during and after high doses of psilocybin and methylphenidate to assess how psychedelics can change human brain networks, and psilocybin was found to massively disrupt functional connectivity in cortex and subcortex with some changes persisting for weeks.
item.dc:title: Psilocybin desynchronizes the human brain

item.title: A eukaryotic-like ubiquitination system in bacterial antiviral defence
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07730-4

A study reports the structure and molecular mechanism of the Bil anti-phage defence system, demonstrating that it is the closest prokaryotic homologue of canonical eukaryotic ubiquitination pathways.
item.dc:title: A eukaryotic-like ubiquitination system in bacterial antiviral defence
item.dc:creator: Lydia R. Chambers
Qiaozhen Ye
Jiaxi Cai
Minheng Gong
Hannah E. Ledvina
Huilin Zhou
Aaron T. Whiteley
Raymond T. Suhandynata
Kevin D. Corbett

item.title: A holistic platform for accelerating sorbent-based carbon capture
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07683-8

A framework that integrates materials, process design, techno-economics and life-cycle assessment can be used to accelerate the development of carbon-capture technology as we aim for a net-zero world.
item.dc:title: A holistic platform for accelerating sorbent-based carbon capture
item.dc:creator: Charithea Charalambous
Elias Moubarak
Johannes Schilling

Susana Garcia

item.title: Identification of plant transcriptional activation domains
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07707-3

A high-throughput yeast-based assay is used to identify more than 1,500 activation domains (ADs) in Arabidopsis transcription factors, and a deep learning approach applied to this dataset can predict AD activity on the basis of sequence features.
item.dc:title: Identification of plant transcriptional activation domains
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Morffy
Lisa Van den Broeck

item.title: Position-dependent function of human sequence-specific transcription factors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07662-z

The effect of transcription factor binding on transcription initiation is dependent on the position of the transcription factor binding site.
item.dc:title: Position-dependent function of human sequence-specific transcription factors
item.dc:creator: Sascha H. Duttke
Carlos Guzman
Max Chang
Nathaniel P. Delos Santos
Bayley R. McDonald
Jialei Xie
Aaron F. Carlin
Sven Heinz
Christopher Benner

item.title: Groundwater-dependent ecosystem map exposes global dryland protection needs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07702-8

Mapping of groundwater-dependent ecosystems, which support biodiversity and rural livelihoods, shows they occur on more than one-third of global drylands analysed, but lack protections to safeguard these critical ecosystems and the societies dependent upon them from groundwater depletion.
item.dc:title: Groundwater-dependent ecosystem map exposes global dryland protection needs
item.dc:creator: Melissa M. Rohde

item.title: Singular dielectric nanolaser with atomic-scale field localization
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07674-9

Singularity enables breaking the optical diffraction limit in a dielectric nanolaser.
item.dc:title: Singular dielectric nanolaser with atomic-scale field localization
item.dc:creator: Yun-Hao Ouyang
Hong-Yi Luan
Zi-Wei Zhao
Wen-Zhi Mao
Ren-Min Ma

item.title: Mechanical release of homogenous proteins from supramolecular gels
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07580-0

A stiff hydrogel gel is presented that encapsulates and stabilizes proteins without additives or excipients and uses mechanical strain to release them, offering low-cost and versatile delivery of therapies.
item.dc:title: Mechanical release of homogenous proteins from supramolecular gels
item.dc:creator: Simona Bianco
Muhammad Hasan
Ashfaq Ahmad
Sarah-Jane Richards
Bart Dietrich
Matthew Wallace
Qiao Tang
Andrew J. Smith
Matthew I. Gibson
Dave J. Adams

item.title: Clonal inactivation of TERT impairs stem cell competition
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07700-w

Studies in mice show that telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT) has a role in enhancing stem cell competition that is independent of its reverse transcriptase activity, and promotes chromatin accessibility and activity of the MYC oncogene.
item.dc:title: Clonal inactivation of TERT impairs stem cell competition
item.dc:creator: Kazuteru Hasegawa
Yang Zhao
Alina Garbuzov
M. Ryan Corces
Patrick Neuhöfer
Victoria M. Gillespie
Peggie Cheung
Julia A. Belk
Yung-Hsin Huang
Yuning Wei
Lu Chen
Howard Y. Chang
Steven E. Artandi

item.title: Sources of gene expression variation in a globally diverse human cohort
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07708-2

A new open-access RNA sequencing dataset, MAGE, of 731 individuals across geographically diverse human populations provides a valuable resource to study genetic diversity and evolution and expands the capacity to identify new genetic associations.
item.dc:title: Sources of gene expression variation in a globally diverse human cohort
item.dc:creator: Dylan J. Taylor
Surya B. Chhetri
Michael G. Tassia
Arjun Biddanda
Stephanie M. Yan
Genevieve L. Wojcik
Alexis Battle
Rajiv C. McCoy

item.title: Sunlight-powered sustained flight of an ultralight micro aerial vehicle
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07609-4

Solar-powered, untethered, sustained flight of an ultralight micro aerial vehicle under natural sunlight conditions is achieved using an electrostatic-driven propulsion system with a high lift-to-power efficiency.
item.dc:title: Sunlight-powered sustained flight of an ultralight micro aerial vehicle
item.dc:creator: Wei Shen
Jinzhe Peng
Rui Ma
Jiaqing Wu
Jingyi Li
Zhiwei Liu
Jiaming Leng
Xiaojun Yan
Mingjing Qi

item.title: Tubulin code eraser CCP5 binds branch glutamates by substrate deformation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07699-0

Cryo-electron microscopy and X-ray structures of the glutamylation eraser CCP5 in complexes with glutamylated microtubules and tubulin tails show that the substrate backbone adopts a bent conformation that presents the branch glutamate to a substrate-binding pocket on CCP5.
item.dc:title: Tubulin code eraser CCP5 binds branch glutamates by substrate deformation
item.dc:creator: Jiayi Chen
Elena A. Zehr
James M. Gruschus
Agnieszka Szyk
Yanjie Liu
Martin E. Tanner
Nico Tjandra
Antonina Roll-Mecak

item.title: Bacteria conjugate ubiquitin-like proteins to interfere with phage assembly
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07616-5

To mitigate phage infection, an antiphage defence system in bacteria conjugates a ubiquitin-like protein to a structural protein of the phage, demonstrating that conjugation of ubiquitin-like proteins is an antiviral strategy conserved across all life forms.
item.dc:title: Bacteria conjugate ubiquitin-like proteins to interfere with phage assembly
item.dc:creator: Jens Hör
Sharon G. Wolf
Rotem Sorek

item.title: In vivo single-cell CRISPR uncovers distinct TNF programmes in tumour evolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07663-y

A CRISPR-based strategy for screening genes that affect clonal expansion finds that genes that are frequently mutated in squamous cell carcinoma converge on a TNF signalling module involving macrophages.
item.dc:title: In vivo single-cell CRISPR uncovers distinct TNF programmes in tumour evolution
item.dc:creator: Peter F. Renz
Umesh Ghoshdastider
Simona Baghai Sain
Fabiola Valdivia-Francia

Stephanie J. Ellis
Andreas E. Moor
Ataman Sendoel

item.title: Split intein-mediated protein trans-splicing to express large dystrophins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07710-8

A method is developed for expressing large dystrophins to enhance muscle function in mouse models of muscular dystrophy, with potential clinical benefits for numerous disorders caused by mutations in large genes that exceed the adeno-associated virus capacity.
item.dc:title: Split intein-mediated protein trans-splicing to express large dystrophins
item.dc:creator: Hichem Tasfaout
Christine L. Halbert
Timothy S. McMillen
James M. Allen
Theodore R. Reyes
Galina V. Flint
Dirk Grimm
Stephen D. Hauschka
Michael Regnier
Jeffrey S. Chamberlain

item.title: Mice live longer when inflammation-boosting protein is blocked
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02298-5

Humans also have the protein, called IL-11, offering hope for a future longevity treatment.
item.dc:title: Mice live longer when inflammation-boosting protein is blocked
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: A psychedelic state arises from desynchronized brain activity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02154-6

After a person takes the psychedelic compound psilocybin, some of their brain networks dissolve — especially the one involved in the perception of self, space and time. Changes to the connections to this network can last for weeks.
item.dc:title: A psychedelic state arises from desynchronized brain activity
item.dc:creator: Petros D. Petridis

item.title: Daily briefing: The poetry hidden in PhD thesis acknowledgements
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02362-0

Science writer Tabitha Carvan explores the found poetry in the acknowledgement sections of PhD theses. Plus, researchers should explore the alternatives to animal research and can H5N1 spread through cow sneezes?
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: The poetry hidden in PhD thesis acknowledgements
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: The search for superconductivity just got wider
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02232-9

Compounds containing copper have long been targeted in the search for high-temperature superconductivity, but experiments performed at extreme pressures suggest that nickel-based materials might also be candidates.
item.dc:title: The search for superconductivity just got wider
item.dc:creator: Weiwei Xie

item.title: Your brain on shrooms — how psilocybin resets neural networks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02275-y

The psychedelic drug causes some lasting changes to the communication pathways that connect distinct brain regions.
item.dc:title: Your brain on shrooms — how psilocybin resets neural networks
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Make gene therapies more available by manufacturing them in lower-income nations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02310-y

Gene therapies will become more affordable everywhere only if they are developed and manufactured in the regions of the world most in need of them.
item.dc:title: Make gene therapies more available by manufacturing them in lower-income nations
item.dc:creator: Evelyn Mwesigwa Harlow
Jennifer E. Adair

item.title: Threading the needle
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02195-x

How time flies.
item.dc:title: Threading the needle
item.dc:creator: Elis Montgomery

item.title: Forest-degradation thresholds shape tropical biodiversity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02155-5

Can forest-degradation thresholds be identified to assess whether logged sites have conservation value? A long-term multi-species study reveals the effects on biodiversity when tropical forests are logged at differing intensities.
item.dc:title: Forest-degradation thresholds shape tropical biodiversity
item.dc:creator: Umesh Srinivasan

item.title: Things fall into place: how plants sense and respond to gravity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01747-5

How plants sense their orientation in relation to gravity and steer their root and shoot growth accordingly is not fully understood. The discovery of key steps needed for this process fills in some of the gaps in our knowledge.
item.dc:title: Things fall into place: how plants sense and respond to gravity
item.dc:creator: Suruchi Roychoudhry
Stefan Kepinski

item.title: The ‘PhD influencers’ logging lab life on TikTok and Instagram
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02294-9

Graduate students are building big followings, making money and overturning science stereotypes by posting on social media.
item.dc:title: The ‘PhD influencers’ logging lab life on TikTok and Instagram
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: Gel protects therapeutic proteins from deactivation — even in the post
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02233-8

The need to keep therapeutic proteins, such as insulin, constantly cold can limit access to life-saving medicines. An advanced gel offers a possible solution to this issue — and might solve problems beyond health-care logistics.
item.dc:title: Gel protects therapeutic proteins from deactivation — even in the post
item.dc:creator: Yanxian Zhang
Danny Hung-Chieh Chou

item.title: Generative AI makes for better scientific writing — but beware the pitfalls
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02319-3

Generative AI makes for better scientific writing — but beware the pitfalls
item.dc:title: Generative AI makes for better scientific writing — but beware the pitfalls
item.dc:creator: Zhongkai Liao
Congcong Zhang

item.title: The pandemic agreement: an African perspective
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02317-5

The pandemic agreement: an African perspective
item.dc:title: The pandemic agreement: an African perspective
item.dc:creator: Nicaise Ndembi
Gerald Mboowa
Sofonias K. Tessema
Yenew Kebede Tebeje
Jean Kaseya

item.title: The death forecast: how weather affects human mortality
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02230-x

A link between the death rate and summer temperatures, and Lord Kelvin’s scientific achievements celebrated, in our weekly dip into Nature’s archive.
item.dc:title: The death forecast: how weather affects human mortality

item.title: Abandoning randomized controlled trials won’t help cancer treatment
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02318-4

Abandoning randomized controlled trials won’t help cancer treatment
item.dc:title: Abandoning randomized controlled trials won’t help cancer treatment
item.dc:creator: Lorenzo Fornaro
Francesco Crea

item.title: Dogs might have evolved to read your emotions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02320-w

Emotional contagion between humans and canines comes from centuries of selective breeding, suggests a comparison with pet pigs.
item.dc:title: Dogs might have evolved to read your emotions
item.dc:creator: Freda Kreier

item.title: A minimalistic model achieves long-range explainable El Niño forecasts with high accuracy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02335-3

A conceptual model provides accurate forecasts of the El Niño–Southern Oscillation (ENSO) climate phenomenon 16–18 months in advance, outperforming global climate models and rivalling the best forecasts using artificial-intelligence methods. The model quantifies the effects of ocean climate patterns on ENSO predictability.
item.dc:title: A minimalistic model achieves long-range explainable El Niño forecasts with high accuracy

item.title: AI & robotics briefing: What is AI, really?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02354-0

Complex maths or almost magic: scholars are divided on what AI really is and what it is capable of. Plus, AI analysis helps to unravel sperm whales’ phonetic alphabet and algorithm predicts chemical composition of salt stains.
item.dc:title: AI & robotics briefing: What is AI, really?
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Reverse engineering spinal-cord injury
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02307-7

A compilation of four single-cell and spatial atlases of spinal-cord injury in mice enables researchers to uncover the principles governing biological responses to such injuries. These discoveries are used to develop a gene therapy that can restore neurological functions in mice.
item.dc:title: Reverse engineering spinal-cord injury

item.title: Animal research is not always king: researchers should explore the alternatives
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02314-8

Technological advances can reduce the numbers of laboratory animals used in studies — but they need to be carefully validated.
item.dc:title: Animal research is not always king: researchers should explore the alternatives

item.title: The geneticist who uses science to free parents wrongly convicted of killing their children
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02324-6

Carola Vinuesa describes how her career changed after identifying a genetic mutation that helped to secure the freedom of Kathleen Folbigg, who was serving a 30-year jail term for killing her four children.
item.dc:title: The geneticist who uses science to free parents wrongly convicted of killing their children
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Plackett

item.title: Daily briefing: When you should throw away expired reagents
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02346-0

Some lab reagents can work decades beyond their best-before date. Plus, the deepest known pit on the Moon seems to lead to a huge underground cave.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: When you should throw away expired reagents
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Severe turbulence ahead — how scientists can keep air travellers safe in a warming world
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02315-7

From weakening jet streams to causing bumpier flights, climate change is altering atmospheric behaviour. Researchers need to find out how.
item.dc:title: Severe turbulence ahead — how scientists can keep air travellers safe in a warming world
item.dc:creator: Haoxuan Yu

item.title: Freezer holding world’s biggest ancient-ice archive to get ‘future-proofed’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02287-8

Repository of samples drilled from glaciers and ice caps is replacing a coolant that can harm the ozone layer.
item.dc:title: Freezer holding world’s biggest ancient-ice archive to get ‘future-proofed’
item.dc:creator: Nicola Jones

item.title: Can H5N1 spread through cow sneezes? Experiment offers clues
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02322-8

Study suggests the virus can spread through the respiratory system but infected milk is probably driving the outbreak in the US.
item.dc:title: Can H5N1 spread through cow sneezes? Experiment offers clues
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: Many plant names are offensive: botanists will vote on whether to change them
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02337-1

Researchers at an international meeting will also consider how to monitor names that have problematic roots.
item.dc:title: Many plant names are offensive: botanists will vote on whether to change them
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Serpents of the people: how a religious festival helps me to monitor snake behaviour
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02313-9

Ernesto Filippi tracks the health of captured specimens thanks to a citizen-science project inspired by an ancient ritual.
item.dc:title: Serpents of the people: how a religious festival helps me to monitor snake behaviour
item.dc:creator: Francesco Martinelli

item.title: Science on the edge: how extreme outdoor skills enhanced our fieldwork
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02311-x

Researchers describe how they developed extraordinary physical skills for their research and how to stay calm in the face of risks.
item.dc:title: Science on the edge: how extreme outdoor skills enhanced our fieldwork
item.dc:creator: Shihab Jamal

item.title: Your reagent is past its use-by date. Should you bin it?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02312-w

Some products are perfectly fine to use after their expiration date — if quality-control tests check out.
item.dc:title: Your reagent is past its use-by date. Should you bin it?
item.dc:creator: Diana Kwon

item.title: Daily briefing: The last universal common ancestor lived around 4.2 billion years ago
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02341-5

The shared forebearer of all life probably ate carbon dioxide and hydrogen. Plus, what Twisters gets right (and wrong) about today’s storm chasers and how to enhance your fieldwork with extreme outdoor skills.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: The last universal common ancestor lived around 4.2 billion years ago
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: The Napoleonic tweets, Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02295-8

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: The Napoleonic tweets, Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: What Twisters gets right — and wrong — about tornado science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02276-x

Nature talks to tornado specialists and scientific advisers for the new disaster film about how it stacks up.
item.dc:title: What Twisters gets right — and wrong — about tornado science
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: This kids’ brain cancer is incurable — but immune therapy holds promise
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02255-2

CAR-T therapy, which harnesses a person’s own immune cells, racks up some astonishing success stories against deadly brain tumours in children.
item.dc:title: This kids’ brain cancer is incurable — but immune therapy holds promise
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Daily briefing: How nations are preparing for a possible H5N1 bird flu pandemic
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02330-8

Countries are ramping up surveillance of avian influenza, purchasing vaccines and developing new ones. Plus, the first fossil chromosomes ever discovered have been found in skin samples from a woolly mammoth.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: How nations are preparing for a possible H5N1 bird flu pandemic
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Bird flu could become a human pandemic. How are countries preparing?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02237-4

Wealthy nations are purchasing vaccines against H5N1 influenza and boosting surveillance, but there are concerns that low-income countries will be left behind.
item.dc:title: Bird flu could become a human pandemic. How are countries preparing?
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: Microbiologist wins case against university over harassment during COVID
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02256-1

Court finds University of Auckland breached obligations to protect Siouxsie Wiles while she provided public information about the pandemic.
item.dc:title: Microbiologist wins case against university over harassment during COVID
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: Pension planning and psychosocial support: how institutions can help academics at the late career stage
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02296-7

Julie Gould looks at some of the schemes develped by universities to prepare staff for life in retirement.
item.dc:title: Pension planning and psychosocial support: how institutions can help academics at the late career stage
item.dc:creator: Julie Gould

item.title: Maggie Aderin-Pocock on diversity: ‘It’s hard to find an argument against it’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02303-x

The space scientist and broadcaster describes how she deals with racism, taps dyslexia’s hidden powers and inspires disadvantaged students to pursue science careers.
item.dc:title: Maggie Aderin-Pocock on diversity: ‘It’s hard to find an argument against it’
item.dc:creator: Audrey Thompson
